2. using shared aesthetics as a signal of belonging
3. coordinating a collective design process.

speakers.name: Ira Nezhynska
speakers.description:
Ira is an independent designer specializing in branding and visual design strategy. After years in the consumer and fintech branding realms, she joined Web3 in early 2018 and has since served as a Creative Director at companies big and small, helping founders win hearts and minds of early adopters and funders. 
These days, she runs her own design practice and conducts DIY (design-it-yourself) workshops for pre- and seed-stage companies.

items.title: Defragmenting Ethereum - Interoperability and the Superchain
items.description:
With the proliferation of L2s and Dencun (4844), Ethereum has scaled. However, we have a new challenge -- fragmentation.

Now we're introducing various interoperability standards across Ethereum and Superchain ecosystem from intents to low latency cross chain bridging primitives. What are these standards and what will enable? How can we create scalable and composable blockspace which enables application developers to onboard the rest of the internet?

speakers.name: Karl Floersch
speakers.description: Started out at ConsenSys building applications, then moved into the core protocol at the Ethereum Foundation, then started work on L2 scalability with Plasma Group which evolved into L2 scalability and public goods funding at Optimism.

items.title: Hardhat v3 will launch soon: precise L2s simulation, performant Rust rewrite, Solidity tests, deployments, and more.
items.description: The Hardhat team has been working continuously over the past two years to redesign and rewrite Hardhat from the ground up, including a major migration to Rust already in production. This talk will explore the problems and solutions that Hardhat‚Äôs upcoming v3 release will focus on: performance, Solidity tests, correct L2 network simulation, and a comprehensive deployment system.

speakers.name: Patricio Palladino
speakers.description: Patricio is the creator of Hardhat, and the co-founder & CTO of Nomic Foundation.

items.title: Making defensive technology offensive: How to get cypherpunk ideals to the masses
items.description: Cryptography is an inherently defensive tool; it hides your information from adversaries. This is crucial to prevent censorship or monitoring of your data. But it's often sold to consumers with fearmongering about all-powerful malicious actors, which is often ignored by all except the privacy-conscious. We explore real-life examples of offensive cryptographic affordances like interoperability, efficiency, and user consent as stronger motivations for the masses to migrate to cypherpunk tech.
items.tags: Frameworks,Values,Use cases of cryptography,messaging,Frameworks,Use cases of cryptography,Values

speakers.name: Vivek Bhupatiraju
speakers.description: Cryptographer and designer @ Cursive, working on cryptography for human connection

items.title: Tending the Infinite Garden: Organizational Culture in the Ethereum Ecosystem
items.description: This presentation will discuss the findings of the academic paper "Tending the Infinite Garden: Organisational Culture in the Ethereum Ecosystem" by Dr. Paul-Dylan-Ennis and Ann Brody. Our study examines the decision-making processes fundamental to Ethereum's protocol governance, drawing on interviews with Ethereum's core developers. We identify a central worldview in Ethereum known as the "Infinite Garden" and discuss how Ethereum's social layer is crucial for upholding cypherpunk values.

speakers.name: Ann Brody
speakers.description: Ann Brody is a dedicated researcher with a focus on blockchain communities and governance, blending insights from Communication Studies and Anthropology in her work. Her primary research interests revolve around Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs), decentralized governance design, crypto politics, and ideologies. Ann thrives at the intersection of industry and academia, where she actively contributes to various projects in the field.

items.title: Unlocking New Possibilities with Stateless Architecture in Layer 2
items.description: Explore the potential of stateless architecture in Layer 2 solutions. As Layer 2 technologies evolve, we will discuss the fundamental trade-offs and present how combining client-side Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) with stateless architecture enhances efficiency. This session will highlight innovative possibilities not yet widely discussed in the Ethereum community, showing how this approach can revolutionize scalability, security, and privacy.

speakers.name: Leona Hioki
speakers.description:
Founder of INTMAX which is building the largest and most stateless infrastructure on Ethereum for asset transfers. 
After winning the IPA Security Camp, he has been involved in security and privacy. Since 2018, He has been part of the Plasma research community. Following an Ethereum Foundation Grant, Leona launched the INTMAX network based on my research achievements

items.title: From Packets to Privacy: Understanding and Evolving Network Security
items.description: This talk will provide a comprehensive journey through the fundamentals of network communication, explore the workings and risks of Virtual Private Networks (VPNs), and dive into the world of Mixnets. We‚Äôll discuss how decentralized Mixnets can offer privacy by default, potentially eliminating the need for traditional VPNs.

speakers.name: Max Hampshire
speakers.description: Max is Senior Developer Relations at Nym Technologies, building developer tooling, SDKs, and example projects for developers who wish to build the new internet free from mass surveillance. Prior to joining Nym he was a Smart Contract developer and artist with an academic background in Political Philosophy and the Philosophy of Technology.

speakers.name: Med Amor
speakers.description: Med is a core contributor at Nym Technologies, a company dedicated to developing a decentralized Mixnet to combat mass surveillance. Before joining Nym, Med he held roles in Legal and Compliance where he advised and contributed to different projects.

items.title: Comparing Slashing Penalties on Proof-of-Stake Networks
items.description: With the support of the Ethereum Foundation, we have performed an analysis of slashing penalties on the seventy largest proof-of-stake cryptocurrency networks. Using insights from institutional economics and game theory, we consider variance in slashing penalties in terms of the conditions that trigger slashing, the magnitude of penalties contemplated, and the limited cases where human judgment plays a role in determining such penalties.

speakers.name: Eric Alston
speakers.description: Eric Alston is a Scholar in Residence in Finance at CU Boulder. Eric‚Äôs research is centered in the fields of law and economics and institutional and organizational analysis, which he applies to research questions in the development of rights along frontiers, the design of constitutions, and digital governance challenges with an emphasis on cryptocurrencies and blockchain networks. Eric also consults directly with numerous cryptocurrency networks and DAOs on their governance dilemmas.

items.title: Solarpunk vs. Lunarpunk: The Evolution and Integration of these Movements
items.description: In this talk, I will explore how the ideals of solarpunk and lunarpunk can be integrated to address privacy, inclusivity, and justice.  We will explain how combining the strengths of both movements we can potentially create a cohesive vision for a sustainable, equitable, and free future.

speakers.name: ManuAlzuru
speakers.description:
ManuAlzuru founder of ETHBarcelona and Blockravers, a crypto nomad community that creates cultural experiences around the world specially around Ethereum events.

Founding member of API3.org, Partner at Own.fund, Member of MetaCartel and advisor to multiple web3 projects.

items.title: Alaska
items.description: Join us at the Music Stage in the social area on Floor G for an unforgettable experience with the Open Source Orchestra! Dive into the beats and vibes curated by talented musicians from the Ethereum ecosystem, bringing together community, creativity, and rhythm. Let‚Äôs groove and connect through the universal language of music!

items.title: White Rabbit World Premiere
items.description:
White Rabbit is the first crowdfunded anime on Ethereum. It is about the metaphorical journey of going down the crypto rabbit hole. White Rabbit follows Mirai, who embarks on a path to discover the meaning of free will and self-sovereignty. There will be a seed phrase scavenger hunt in the final act of the film.

Directed by pplpleasr and Maciej Kuciara, run time 30 minutes

speakers.name: Pplpleasr
speakers.description: pplpleasr is known for her early work in DeFi, such as the Uniswap v3 video, as well as making the cover of Fortune Magazine in August 2021. She was also in Forbes 30u30 2022, and her work inspired the formation of PleasrDAO. She has since founded Shibuya, a new age creator platform for short films built on Ethereum.

items.title: Better privacy defaults for your users with stealth addresses
items.description:
Stealth addresses can be used to give users better privacy from payments to identity. In this workshop we will run through practical use cases of stealth addresses today and how they relate to different types of products.

We will then have a short coding session where we will implement stealth addresses to generate private Safe signers from scratch.

speakers.name: Antonio Seveso
speakers.description:
I've been involved full-time in the blockchain space since 2020, but experimenting with the tech on a personal level since 2013, mostly on privacy-focused solutions.
With a full-stack background, I define myself a solidity dev with an architectural view when it comes to develop applications in Web3. Currently I'm the Co-founder of Fluidkey, bringing default-privacy with great UX on EVMs.
Outside blockchain space, I'm a basketball lover, LEGO nerd and roller-coaster enthusiast.

speakers.name: Moritz Boullenger
speakers.description: Moritz is the co-founder of Fluidkey. He is focused on improving privacy defaults and usability on public blockchains.

items.title: Building a Basic Smart Contract with Scaffold-ETH
items.description: In this session, Kevin will help you create a basic smart contract using Scaffold-ETHv2. It's a hands-on way to learn the basics of writing and deploying contracts on Ethereum.

speakers.name: Kevin Jones
speakers.description: Kevin Jones is a core member of the Buidl Guidl and a Developer Relations Engineer at The Graph

items.title: EVM Object Format (EOF): Managing the Bytecode Chaos
items.description:
Currently, EVM bytecode, while being powerful and simple, is lacking structure. This leads to many complexities when introducing new EIPs and maintaining backwards compatibility.

In this talk, we illustrate some use cases of the EVM Object Format (EOF). Next, we provide a quick overview of the main changes introduced by the EOF and related EIPs, along with code examples. Finally, we discuss potential benefits and drawbacks that could arise with the introduction of EOF

speakers.name: Alex Murashkin
speakers.description: Alex is a senior software engineer with extensive knowledge of security, distributed computing, and decentralized systems. He holds a Master of Mathematics degree in Computer Science from the University of Waterloo (Canada), where he worked on techniques for design exploration and optimization in satisfiability-related problems.

items.title: How To Hallucinate A Server
items.description: A Hallucinated Server is a virtual server whose execution is cryptographically simulated by users, using "multiplayer" privacy technologies like multi-party computation or fully homomorphic encryption. Today, thanks to recent advancements in MPC and FHE, we have the technology to build the first fully Turing-complete hallucinated servers. We discuss the underlying technologies, and how we've used them to build several proof-of-concept applications.

speakers.name: gubsheep
speakers.description: gubsheep is co-founder of 0xPARC and creator of the Dark Forest game.

items.title: Issuance Endgame: Stake Targeting
items.description:
This talk explores the status quo of staking economics, its drawbacks as we see them and what the endgame of staking economics could look like. 

We argue that it should include an issuance policy that targets a range of staking ratios instead. The intention is to be secure enough but avoid overpaying for security and thereby enabling said negative externalities.

speakers.name: Ansgar Dietrichs
speakers.description: Researcher @ Ethereum Foundation

speakers.name: Caspar Schwarz-Schilling
speakers.description: Research

items.title: Smart Accounts need Smart Sessions
items.description: The world of dapps is evolving and wallets are becoming smarter. This is powered by developments in Smart Accounts which unlock more user-friendly experiences. Learn about how WalletConnect is introducing Smart Sessions and walkthrough all the standards (EIPs, ERCs and CAIPs) that will make the future of wallet UX possible.

speakers.name: Pedro Gomes
speakers.description: Founder of WalletConnect and developing Ethereum wallet infrastructure since 2018. Additionally a founding member of Chain Agnostic Standards Alliance (CASA) and authored of several Ethereum Improvement Proposals (EIPs) focused wallet interoperability.

items.title: The Age of Account Abstraction: Opportunities and Challenges
items.description: In a world where the web3 user experience is streamlined through account abstraction, complexities like gas and multiple L1s/L2s are hidden from users. This talk explores the competitive dynamics likely to develop at each layer of the stack (layers, DeFi protocols, intent protocols) and the strategies that might be employed to succeed. Join me to delve into the transformative impact of making Web3 seamless and accessible, and understand how to navigate and thrive in this evolving landscape.

speakers.name: Daniel Yanev
speakers.description:
CEO and co-founder of Rhino.fi 
University of Cambridge alumnus

Great products are build by great companies.

items.title: Utilizing national IDs in the Ethereum ecosystem
items.description: This panel brings together developers of MynaWallet, Anon-Aadhaar, Proof of Passport and zkPassport, who are exploring and developing applications that utilize government-issued IDs in the Ethereum ecosystem. We will discuss the characteristics of each ID system and what functions can be realized using tech stacks in the Ethereum ecosystem and cryptographic technology.

speakers.name: Florent
speakers.description:
Zero-knowledge cryptography.
Working on https://www.proofofpassport.com/

speakers.name: Hiroyuki Tachibana
speakers.description: Co-founder & CEO of a42x Inc., building MynaWallet - an ERC-4337 smart wallet transforming Japan's national ID cards into secure crypto wallets

speakers.name: Michael Elliot
speakers.description: Michael is a research engineer with a focus on blockchain, cryptography, and zero-knowledge proofs.

speakers.name: nico
speakers.description: Hi, I'm nico from Japan! I'm really into decentralized tech and cryptography, especially around Ethereum. Right now, I'm doing blockchain research at Kyoto University and developing identity-related projects on the side.

speakers.name: Yanis
speakers.description: Software Engineer @PrivacyScalingExplorations

items.title: VLSMs‚Äîanalyzing faulty distributed systems
items.description: Validating Labeled State transition and Message production systems (VLSMs) provide a general approach to modeling and verifying faulty distributed systems. With formal definitions of validation and equivocation, we are able to prove that for systems of validators, the impact of Byzantine components is indistinguishable from the effect of the introduction of corresponding equivocating components. All of the results presented in this talk have been formalized and checked in the Coq proof assistant
items.tags: Consensus,Distributed validator technology,Formal Verification,correct-by-construction,Consensus,Distributed validator technology,Formal Verification

speakers.name: Vlad Zamfir
speakers.description: Vlad Zamfir is a renowned blockchain researcher and software developer who has made significant contributions to the Ethereum network. He is widely recognized for his work on the proof-of-stake (PoS) consensus algorithm.

items.title: Hacking Thai Beats, Cities & Dances
items.description: Can we inspire Thai builders to be more creative through hacking our own culture? Stories of an algorithmic Thai music festival in Thailand's oldest museum, an open-source hackathon to improve the city of Bangkok, an interactive art performance that blends algorithms with traditional Thai dance; and how you can build better builder communities by inter-disciplinary thinking.

speakers.name: Phoomparin Mano
speakers.description: Poom is a frontend engineer at Metabase based in Bangkok, Thailand. He's a big fan of cute plushies, black cat, macarons, Onsen baths, and jet skis. He co-founded Creatorsgarten, a group of developers and creative people, and they've hosted over 50 events and hackathons in Thailand for the past 8 years. He works on nerdy side projects such as visual asssembly canvas, and collaborate with artists to build art projects.

items.title: Product-Led Blockchain Development
items.description:
As teams spin up new app-specific rollups and L2s, we've moved into an era of product-led blockchain development. In this model, developers are not only building the first product or client to leverage their protocol, but establishing what ‚Äòproduct-defined blockspace‚Äô means. 

In this talk, I go over the history of product-led growth, how it evolved to product-led protocol development in web3, and finally, what product-led blockchain development means in the context of app-specific rollups.

speakers.name: Gregory Rocco
speakers.description: Rocco is the Head of Portfolio at Ethereal Ventures, a co-founder and product advisor to SpruceID, which gives individuals back control over their digital selves, and prior to that he helped lead digital identity initiatives at ConsenSys.

items.title: [CLS] ETH Escape - Speed Hacking Challenge
items.description:
‚ÄãPrize Pool: $50,000

‚ÄãA High-Stakes Speed Hacking/ CTF Challenge
Are you ready to dive headfirst into a thrilling web3 adventure? Join us for ETH Escape, a heart-pounding Speed Hacking & Capture the Flag (CTF) challenge designed to test your coding skills and problem-solving abilities on Ethereum.

https://lu.ma/viyjky8t

items.title: FOSSify yourself for privacy and security
items.description:
You will leave this workshop at least a bit more cypherpunk than when you came. The session will introduce FOSS stack of tools for all platforms. We will discuss free operating systems, GNU/Linux distros, GrapheneOS, secure communication, browsing, hardware options and secure environment for handling your crypto or Ethereum validators.
The workshop is interactive and open to anyone to participate. Join us to find free and open solutions to your problems or come to share your favorite foss tools!

speakers.name: Mario Havel
speakers.description: EF Protocol Support

items.title: MUD past, present, and future
items.description:
Opening talk for the MUD Day CLS, from MUD core developer Alvarius. 

Join us as Alvarius gives a brief review of the history of MUD the framework and the MUD community leading up to today, and a sneak peak into the future of MUD.

items.title: The d/acc Vision: Balancing Progress and Protection
items.description: A one-day summit focusing on the theme of d/acc: emphasizing the values of decentralization, democracy, differential accelerated progress, and defensive tech including crypto security, public epistemics, bio defense,  neurotech/longevity, decentralized ai and physical resilience.
items.track: [CLS] d/acc Discovery Day: Building Towards a Resilient Utopia

items.title: The Open Source Orchestra
items.description: Member of the Open Source Orchestra

speakers.name: Sophia Spirlock
speakers.description: Former Concert Pianist / Former DataViz / Solidity Dev / NftFi / Builder - Founder

items.title: Chain-abstracted Smart Accounts -- How to Build Amazing Web3 UX in 2024
items.description:
Chain abstraction (CA) and account abstraction (AA) have been two of the hottest topics in Web3, but few people know how to use them together.

In this talk, I will explain how developers can build amazing Web3 experiences by combining AA with CA in the form of "chain-abstracted smart accounts" -- smart accounts that can spend their balances on any chain without bridging.

speakers.name: Derek Chiang
speakers.description:
Derek is the founder and CEO of ZeroDev -- an embedded smart wallet that is powering over 50% of all AA volume in DeFi today.  He is also a co-author of several AA standards including 7679, 7710, and 7715.

Prior to crypto, Derek worked extensively on distributed systems, including cloud orchestration platforms (Pachyderm) and P2P networks (Consul).

items.title: The political economy of d/acc
items.description: The dynamics behind d/acc are not new. Economic history is full of examples of the private provision of public goods. If we want to reduce AI risks while preserving freedom from centralized control, it's worth thinking carefully about the different ways humans have solved isomorphic problems in the past, and how the same tools could apply today.
items.track: [CLS] d/acc Discovery Day: Building Towards a Resilient Utopia

speakers.name: Eli Dourado
speakers.description: Eli Dourado is Chief Economist at the Abundance Institute. He is on a sacred quest to increase the pace of American economic growth. He has published in top newspapers, negotiated global supersonic standards, derailed an international treaty, spent too much time on Twitter, and received a PhD in economics from George Mason University.

items.title: AW RPG - MUD Day Demo
items.description:
This is a project demo as part of the MUD Day CLS: autonomous worlds, onchain games, and non-financial applications.

We make onchain RPG mechanisms to be used by traditional game dev. When separated, each mechanism stands alone as its own game. When combined, AW!

So, five games, five sets of RPG mechanisms:
- Game 1: Base-Defense
- Game 2: Web2 game modded onchain
- Game 3: Turn-based roguelike
- Game 4: Shoot-em-all
- Game 5: Open-World RPG

speakers.name: briefkandle
speakers.description: building onchain rpg... making onchain waifu great again

items.title: Play a massive onchain war game! - MUD Day Demo
items.description: Play Battle for Blockchain, an onchain war game with us. Become the commander of armies and storm your enemies. Collaborate with friends to obliterate opponents and win fortune.

speakers.name: stokarz
speakers.description: onchain games enjoyer

items.title: Achieving Chain Abstraction through Transaction Orchestration
items.description:
Achieving chain abstracted experiences will require the ability to execute multiple transactions across multiple blockchains as a single "action", ideally with a single signature used for permissioning. 

In this talk I'll explore the concepts of transaction orchestration and single-signature, multi-chain permissioning. I will present what are the benefits, how to create such systems and what are the drawbacks (e.g. soft atomicity, stale permissions, etc...)

speakers.name: Mislav Javor
speakers.description: Mislav is a software engineer and founder, working in the blockchain space since 2016. Some notable achievements are: Co-authoring one of the first textbooks on Ethereum development (Developers guide to Ethereum), organizing the first blockchain developers meetup in the Balkans region. Business wise, Mislav has worked as an engineer and manager in several blockchain projects spanning topics as diverse as real world asset tokenization on one end and core protocol research on the other.

items.title: Biomes - MUD Day Demo
items.description:
This is a project demo as part of the MUD Day CLS: autonomous worlds, onchain games, and non-financial applications.

Biomes is growing the virtual world with the largest GDP. As a fully onchain 3D voxel world, every single action in Biomes -- mining, building, crafting, even moving -- is a transaction on the Redstone L2.

speakers.name: Dhvani Patel
speakers.description: building Biomes

items.title: Data science and Ethereum
items.description:
Share insights on how we collect and utilize consensus layer data from devnets, testnets, and mainnet:
- Tools used to extract data from the Ethereum network
- Our current dataset: https://ethpandaops.io/data/xatu/
- Examples of past analyses and their impact on decision-making
- The importance of data science for research, Ethereum improvements and understanding the network
- A demo on interacting with the dataset and how to get started
- Future plans and ways to get involved

speakers.name: Andrew Davis
speakers.description: DevOps in ethPandaOps team

speakers.name: Sam Calder-Mason
speakers.description: DevOps Engineer @ EF on the EthPandaOps team

items.title: Decentralizing the Internet's collaboration layer
items.description:
Over half of the world‚Äôs Internet users trust one closed-source, centralized app suite for their daily knowledge creation and collaboration: Google Workspace.

As a core part of what people use the Internet for, it should offer similar robustness as the Internet does through sufficient decentralization. The decentralized stack required for such apps is now possible. The talk explore this stack and introduces examples of dapps we built with it incl. this year's Devcon's collaboration stack.

speakers.name: Andreas Tsamados
speakers.description: Andreas is the co-founder of Fileverse / ddocs.new and a doctoral researcher at the University of Oxford, focusing on FAI-enabled human-machine teaming in cybersecurity

items.title: Energy Renewal (Sound Healing)
items.description:
By master Ice 
This session helps you rest deeply, reset your energy, and find inner peace.
- Recharge and relax with gentle sounds of gongs and bowls
-  a short guided meditation. 

Nov 14 10:30 -11:15

items.title: Finding rough consensus on issuance
items.description: lido and ef researchers agree on far more than people think. this talk is an attempt to synthesize and explain my take on the big picture as simply as possible with plenty of humour.

speakers.name: Sacha
speakers.description: building lido research

items.title: I don‚Äôt know the name yet
items.description: It will be worth it ;)

speakers.name: Barry Whitehat
speakers.description: N/A

items.title: The Franklin Fallacy: Why We Misjudge New Technologies
items.description: People often dismiss emerging technologies by focusing only on their current limitations, overlooking their potential evolution. This tendency, seen throughout history‚Äîfrom the telegraph to Ethereum‚Äîstems from what can be called ‚ÄúThe Franklin Fallacy.‚Äù When asked about the purpose of a hot air balloon, Benjamin Franklin famously responded, "What good is a newborn baby?" highlighting how judging a technology in its infancy is shortsighted. This talk delves into the psychology of this fallacy.

speakers.name: Louis Anslow
speakers.description: Writer, designer and curator of Pessimists Archive (@PessimistsArc)

items.title: Zoom in on EOF stack validation
items.description: Deep dive into EIP-5450: EOF stack validation spec and explaining some of the rationale behind it.

speakers.name: Andrei Maiboroda
speakers.description: Researcher and developer of the mighty Ipsilon team @ EF. Interested in all things Ethereum Execution Layer. EOF ninja.

items.title: Exploring MUD worlds with Blockscout
items.description:
This is a project demo as part of the MUD Day CLS: autonomous worlds, onchain games, and non-financial applications.
Showcase of the Blockscout features that help users and developers explore any MUD world on-chain.

speakers.name: Kirill Fedoseev
speakers.description: Head of Research at Blockscout

items.title: Neurotech
items.description: A one-day summit focusing on the theme of d/acc: emphasizing the values of decentralization, democracy, differential accelerated progress, and defensive tech including crypto security, public epistemics, bio defense,  neurotech/longevity, decentralized ai and physical resilience.
items.track: [CLS] d/acc Discovery Day: Building Towards a Resilient Utopia

items.title: CafeCosmos - MUD Day Demo
items.description:
This is a project demo as part of the MUD Day CLS: autonomous worlds, onchain games, and non-financial applications.

CafeCosmos is a fully onchain cafe building tycoon. Players are able to earn through redistributive DeFi contracts by speculating on the best earning recipes. 

Build, Farm, Cook, Earn.

speakers.name: Nico Rodriguez
speakers.description: Token Engineer designing the future of Autonomous Worlds and fully onchain games with a focus on decentralization, advanced token systems design, and product development.

items.title: Chain abstraction is risk abstraction
items.description: The talk aims to provide a nuanced view of whether chain abstraction truly enhances user experience or introduces new layers of complexity and vulnerability. We'll explore the concept of chain abstraction, examine various approaches to it, and delve into the associated risks for users, as well as the strategies for mitigating these risks.

speakers.name: Radina Talanova
speakers.description: A Product Owner at L2BEAT, a research and analytics public goods company, focused on providing insights and transparency about the risks associated with Ethereum scaling solutions.

items.title: Cloudlines ü™Ç - MUD Day Demo
items.description:
**CLOUDLINES** is an ode to playing together. It‚Äôs a song about the nights we spend discovering and building our own world and our relationships with each other.

Welcome to an idyllic, chill and romantic multiplayer game about developing your floating island from shanty to city; a persistent collaborative world of townscaping.

speakers.name: Alexander Mangel

items.title: Chain abstraction? But I want to know where my tokens are
items.description: As a space, we face a big problem: how should we think about where assets live. Is Eth different from oEth or aEth. Does it matter where Circle prints your USDC? Should chains delegated to the kind of infra that Google Cloud or AWS is today? Clearly, the fragmentations of USDC/USDT/xDAI and then all the L2s creates horrible UX. However, the underlying assets are different things and the chains they live on have completely different security guarantees. Let's fix this!

speakers.name: Konrad Urban
speakers.description: Co-founder of Peanut Protocol

items.title: Porting Dark Forest to MUD - MUD Day Demo
items.description: We recently ported Dark Forest to the MUD engine and would like to share some of the insights we gained during this process with everyone.

speakers.name: ddy
speakers.description: smart contract & frontend developer in DFArchon team

items.title: Trust-minimized P2P marketplaces on Ethereum
items.description: Blockchains have enabled trustless and fast transaction settlement (i.e. stablecoins, DeFi). However, these existing use cases exist in parallel and are siloed off from the real world. With the maturation of ZK, MPC and other programmable crypto techniques, we are now able to connect data on the internet to blockchains in a trust minimized way for use in smart contracts. This talk will explore the massive design space unlocked for apps (i.e. trust minimized P2P marketplaces)

speakers.name: Richard
speakers.description: Applying Cryptography @ ZKP2P

items.title: EVE Frontier - MUD Day Demo
items.description:
This is a project demo as part of the MUD Day CLS: autonomous worlds, onchain games, and non-financial applications.

EVE Frontier, is a single-shard survival game from CCP Games‚Äîthe creators of the legendary space-based MMO EVE Online.

speakers.name: Toniya Sundaram
speakers.description: I'm a Blockchain engineer with six years of experience in the Ethereum space, working on protocols, open-source projects, and decentralized games. As a speaker at Ethereum events and a hackathon organizer, I'm passionate about autonomous worlds, smart contracts, and zero-knowledge technology. Currently, I‚Äôm building Project Awakening, a sci-fi game on the MUD framework, where players influence the game mechanics through on-chain technology

items.title: NeuroAI for AI safety
items.description: Powerful unaligned AIs pose risks to humans. This talk will explore how neuroscience-inspired AI‚Äìor NeuroAI‚Äìcan lead to a deeper understanding of the human brain, and help us build more secure AI. I‚Äôll connect these ideas to d/acc, arguing that neuroAI can play an enabling role in creating technologies that are inherently defense-favoring and promote human well-being.
items.track: [CLS] d/acc Discovery Day: Building Towards a Resilient Utopia

speakers.name: Patrick Mineault
speakers.description: I‚Äôm a NeuroAI researcher at the Amaranth Foundation, which funds ambitious research in neuroscience. I focus on the intersection of neuroscience and AI safety. I did my B.Sc. in Math and Physics and a PhD in neuroscience at McGill. Previously, I was a software engineer at Google,  a research scientist in brain-computer interfaces at Meta, and a machine learning researcher at Mila.

items.title: Balancing UX and Decentralization: When Does Abstraction Go Too Far?
items.description: Chain abstraction has taken the front seat. As innovations continue, it's becoming increasingly stark that we will eventually approach a world where third-party solvers fulfill most transactions. The core protocol is also changing to cater to further abstractions even at the validator level. The question remains, how far are we willing to go in the name of efficiency, and optimizations, to which a user can't use Ethereum without third parties?

speakers.name: GregTheGreek
speakers.description:
CPO & Co-Founder @ ChainSafe
Co-Founder @ Sygma Labs

items.title: EVMMAX. Fast Modular Arithmetic in EVM
items.description: On the top of EVM Object Format we build an extension which allows contract developers to implement optimized advanced cryptography functions. This feature allows us to implement existing and future ECC precompiles counterparts directly in EVM. Adding new ECC functions (i.e. bls precompiles or  functions based on a new, unknown yet, elliptic curve) to the protocol won't require introducing new precompiles. It can be achieved easier and without any risk for the consensus.

speakers.name: rodiazet
speakers.description: Mathematician, programmer and researcher at EF ipsilon team. Recently focused on EVM, EOF, EVMMAX and ECC.

items.title: For The Kingdom - MUD Day Demo
items.description:
This is a project demo as part of the MUD Day CLS: autonomous worlds, onchain games, and non-financial applications.

For The Kingdom (https://forthekingdom.xyz/) is a web-based MMORPG featuring a player-driven economy and worldbuilding, empowering players to be anyone they want to be.

The game is fully onchain, and currently live on the Redstone Garnet Testnet, using the MUD framework.

speakers.name: Tuyen Dinh
speakers.description: For The Kingdom founder & errand boi. Ex Kyber Network & Krystal DeFi.

items.title: How much security does your restaking protocol really need?
items.description: Restaking protocols have aggregated millions of ETH with the hope of securing new infrastructure on Ethereum. These services, such as ZK provers and oracles, require restaking ETH to enforce custom slashing rules. But how much ETH do these services need? And how much risk do these services place on Ethereum L1? We will formulate a mathematical model for answering these questions and present an empirical analysis of cascading risks from restaking services to Ethereum, with a positive outlook!

items.title: Keynote: Make Ethereum Cypherpunk Again: Why we need privacy
items.description:
The Web3 revolution seeks to address the sins of Web2. However, in doing so, it‚Äôs created an even worse outcome for users  - users‚Äô data is publicly available and makes them vulnerable to state-level censorship and adverse actions.

This talk will address the philosophical as well as practical considerations of privacy in Web3. 
Privacy is an industry-wide issue and sits at the heart of all that is Web3. Understanding why privacy matters involves recognizing that it is not an isolated concept bu

speakers.name: Zac Williamson
speakers.description:
CEO & Co-Founder Aztec Network

Doctorate in Particle Physics from University of Oxford. Former physicist at CERN and T2K Japan. Creator of AZTEC Protocol, co-inventor of PLONK.

items.title: Maximum Viable Security (MVS) ‚Äì a new issuance framework
items.description: We derive a new framework for analyzing Ethereum Issuance, based on Ethereum's core values: security and neutrality. Upon discussing various attacks on Ethereum, we study future growth projections and the importance of diverse validator set, and conclude that Ethereum's defendability is the key factor for issuance policy evaluation. Via MVS, we show how the current issuance reduction proposal is dangerous, based on the future staked ETH concentration with CEXs & impact on solo stakers.

speakers.name: Artem Kotelskiy
speakers.description: For 2013-2023 period I was a pure mathematician, studying low-dimensional topology and symplectic geometry in Princeton, Indiana and Stony Brook Universities. I got interested in crypto as early as 2015, and did some investments and research in Ethereum ecosystem on the side. In 2022 I also taught a course on blockchains in Stony Brook (artofkot.xyz/blockchain-course), and in 2023 move into the space full-time, as a research lead in cyber.fund.

items.title: QuarkID: Bringing South America on-chain with SSI and account Abstraction
items.description: QuarkID is a Self-Sovereign Identity protocol bringing millions of South American citizens on-chain. Citizens in Buenos Aires, Argentina, Monterrey, and Nuevo Leon, Mexico, are using government SSI deployed on ZKsync Era through the QuarkID protocol. Driver's licenses, birth certificates, and over 50 different credentials are secured by Ethereum technology in the world‚Äôs first case of governments using Ethereum‚Äôs permissionless blockchain to meet their identity needs.

speakers.name: Diego Fernandez
speakers.description: Co-creator of @Quark_ID. Former Head of Innovation in Buenos Aires city.

items.title: PopCraft - MUD Day Demo
items.description: This is a project demo for MUD Day CLS: onchain games and non-financial applications. PopCraft is a fully on-chain casual click-based game integrating gameplay with financial elements. Currently in single-player mode, it plans to expand to multiplayer. Built on composability, PopCraft uses PixeLAW, TCM, and Redswap. In-game item issuance and trading are decentralized, transparent, and open, allowing seamless integration of any ERC-20 token projects and DEX.

speakers.name: CK
speakers.description: Founder of MetaCat, building PopCraft and mud.pixelaw.

items.title: Putting Intents and Users Together
items.description: Intents represent a new approach to Web3 interactions. However, the transition from the existing structure to an intent-centric space remains uncertain unless we maintain user familiarity. We conducted experiments on user experience for intents and tested them with a focus group. This talk will explore how we can approach intents in a way that users will adopt more readily by leveraging the latest standards and EIPs, including EIP-7702, ERC-4337, ERC-7579, and ERC-7715.

speakers.name: Abhimanyu Shekhawat
speakers.description:
Abhimanyu is a Co-founder of Epoch Protocol, an Intent-Centric Abstraction layer for web3. He has been in the space for the last 6 years, his previous venture, Orange Wallet, was acquired by a big Ce-Fi company.
He has worked with some of the biggest projects in web3 including Avail, Polygon, Spheron, and Hyperledger, and has contributions across projects like Slyther, Ethereum.org, Wallet Connect, and more.
He has been actively working on the intersection of users and web3 for the last 4 years

items.description:
This is a project demo for MUD Day CLS: onchain games and non-financial applications. 

For the past 1.5 years, I've been building fully onchain games‚Äìgames where the entire state is onchain for some reason (have launched 7!). In this demo, I will showcase some of these games that I have built.

speakers.name: Small Brain
speakers.description: Small Brain is a serial builder of onchain games (& has built >5) in the past year. Some games include Words3 (an infinite onchain word game), Yonk (a mobile app where you can pay your friends to yell at them), draw.tech (a onchain version of r/place) & more.

items.title: Exploring various approaches to achieve effective decentralization for Intent-Based protocols
items.description: Intents are emerging as the gold standard for transacting on-chain. However, they do come with decentralization trade-offs. In this talk, I'd like to present the status quo, various architectures, and new tradeoffs in terms of where they fit in the trilemma of fees, execution speed, and execution guarantees. The objective is to achieve maximum decentralization while maintaining a great UX and efficiency.

speakers.name: Mounir Benchemled

Ultimate Dominion is a fully onchain text-based RPG. Explore the world, defeat monsters, collect, buy, and sell items.

items.title: Argentina‚Äôs Opportunity & the Case for a Special Economic Zone
items.description:
Argentina is uniquely positioned to capitalize on the technological and economic opportunities of this century.  
This talk presents a compelling case for the creation of a Special Economic Zone (SEZ) to drive technological growth and economic prosperity in the country.  Intended to push innovation and attract investment, a SEZ could address Argentina's current challenges, including inflation, infrastructure, and regulatory hurdles.

speakers.name: Maria Milagros Santamaria
speakers.description: Head of Regulatory Department at Crecimiento and Lead of Ops at Architect Systems.

items.title: Behind Zupass: Applied Cryptography For Consumers
items.description:
Recent advancements in cryptography on consumer devices (like your mobile phone) and progress in developer tooling (Semaphore, SnarkJS) have led to the emergence of open-source projects such as Zupass, a personal "cryptographic computer" helping power Devcon.

This talk dives into the technical challenges behind scaling ZKPs to 10,000+ consumer devices and the history behind the project, from its inception at Zuzalu to its usage at recent Ethereum events (Devconnect, ProgCrypto, ETHBerlin).
items.tags: Identity,ZKP,Use cases of cryptography,Mobile,proving,Identity,Use cases of cryptography,ZKP

speakers.name: Richard Liu
speakers.description: Richard works at [0xPARC](0xparc.org) and is a core contributor to the [Zupass project](https://x.com/zupassproject).

items.title: Circles - resilient money
items.description: Circles is an attempt to design money while maximizing decentralization and resilience. Furthermore it tries to find a balance between "newcomers", joining the social contract that any form of money represents, and those already in it.
items.track: [CLS] d/acc Discovery Day: Building Towards a Resilient Utopia

speakers.name: koeppelmann
speakers.description:
Fair money @aboutCircles
Co-founded Gnosis. Supporting @gnosisDAO, @gnosischain, @gnosisSafe, @gnosispay, @cowswap

items.title: Coordination Accelerationism: A Manifesto
items.description: In this talk, we place crypto in the context of evolutionary timescale. We present an overview of the various types of coordination systems, their advantages and weaknesses. The most robust type of coordination mechanism is something we term as, self-enforcing coordination systems (SECS) - which do not require an authority, a committee or even a majority of entities to enforce the conditions of coordination. We also show how to build the most general form of SECS.

speakers.name: Sreeram Kannan
speakers.description: Sreeram Kannan is founder of the EigenLayer protocol, which is a mechanism for shared security on Ethereum. He was previously a tenured professor at University of Washington Seattle, where he ran the UW Blockchain Research Lab.

items.title: Cultivating Culture in Web3: Preserving the Essence as We Evolve
items.description:
Meaningful conversation around the importance of maintaining the unique culture of Ethereum, especially as we continue to grow and attract individuals from traditional  backgrounds. The chat can explore how to uphold the values and ethos that have shaped the web3 community + the higher human needs of belonging, connectedness, and purpose etc.

This would be between myself and Aya

speakers.name: simona pop
speakers.description: it's me

items.title: Practical endgame on issuance policy
items.description: A practical endgame on issuance policy stops the growth in stake while guaranteeing proper consensus incentives and positive regular rewards to solo stakers. Viable reward curves for this endgame are presented. Motivations, impacts and potential downsides of an issuance reduction are in focus. A tangible framework is also introduced: never exceed an issuance rate of 0.5%. A stringent cap on issuance caps the inflation rate, solidifying ETH as trustless sound money with robust economic security.

speakers.name: Anders Elowsson
speakers.description: Anders Elowsson is a researcher at the Ethereum Foundation working on staking economics with a specific focus on issuance policy.

items.title: Revm Endgame
items.description:
Revm is a critical component of the Ethereum ecosystem, used by builders, toolings and clients. It is an audited and proven library that is both fast and easy to use.

As more projects adopt Revm, I feel the increasing burden of making breaking changes and the need to consolidate its functionality. That‚Äôs why I am thinking about Revm Endgame, a solution to support experimentation, Layer 2 features, and EIPs without the need for repository forks.

speakers.name: Dragan Rakita
speakers.description: Revm author, Eth core dev.

items.title: Wallet Infra 101, & where innovation needs to happen
items.description:
In this talk I hope to go over the infrastructure stack of a standard wallet, and then also go into where in this stack I think innovation should happen/is already happening and why that's exciting. This will also broadly cover other related topics such as: 
- The future state of crypto UI & dapp interactions
- What crypto wallets can learn from web2 apps 
- My framework around "What users can do with their balance?", and how wallets can use that to build new features

speakers.name: Medha Kothari
speakers.description: Medha currently does Product for Uniswap Labs. She found herself absolutely enraptured by crypto back in 2017 because of what she learned at Blockchain @ Berkeley, and since then has served in a variety of roles in crypto -- first as a software engineer for the Celo Protocol, then as a VC at Variant Fund, and now as a PM at Uniswap. On nights and weekends she started a nonprofit called she256 to increase diversity in the space.

items.title: Who Wins Ethereum Block Building Auctions and Why?
items.description: Today, top 3 block builders produce over 90% of blocks on Ethereum via MEV-boost auction. The block builder market's dynamics evolve rapidly and has significant impact on the development of private mempools, wallets/apps orderflow auctions, and censorship resistance topic. In this talk, we share an overview of why the top builders win the most market share, using orderflow composition and bidding behavioral data. We hope to highlight the centralizing risks and failures of current market design.

speakers.name: Burak √ñz
speakers.description: Ph.D. candidate at the Technical University of Munich (TUM) and incentives researcher at Flashbots

speakers.name: Danning Sui
speakers.description: Data at [Flashbots](https://flashbots.net/), Research Council at [TLDR Fellowship program](https://www.thelatestindefi.org/), Co-host of [Indexed](https://x.com/indexed_pod) Crypto Data Podcast

items.title: Yeomen.ai - MUD Day Demo
items.description:
This is a project demo for MUD Day CLS: onchain games and non-financial applications. 

Yeomen.ai is building dashboards, automation tools, marketplaces, and platforms for autonomous worlds and onchain games built with MUD. Rohan will showcase some of these tools in this demo session.

speakers.name: Rohan Abraham
speakers.description: Experienced technologist having interests in several technology verticals ranging from Enterprise Software to Startups over a 20 year career.

items.title: Ethereum in the Classroom | Teaching Solidity to High School Students in Buenos Aires
items.description: ETH Kipu is breaking new ground by introducing Ethereum education to teenagers in Argentina. Discover how we collaborated with the Buenos Aires Ministry of Education to create hands-on learning experiences, teaching students to build smart contracts using Solidity. This talk will share best practices from our experience and how it can be replicated globally, sharing the insights we have discovered in the classroom and how we develop this partnership.

speakers.name: Juan David Reyes
speakers.description: Core team member ETH Kipu. Contributing to Ethereum Bogot√° and BuidlGuidl.

speakers.name: Romina Sejas
speakers.description: ETH Kipu & ETH Latam co-founder. Prev. Gov Lead at SEED Latam.

items.title: From MPC Wallets to Smart Contract Accounts
items.description: The proposal outlines a path for the mass adoption of smart contract accounts by using MPC wallet as a transitional solution. Users can start their web3 journey by using MPC wallets which can be done via social login. Later, users can turn the MPC wallets into smart contract wallets using EIP-7702, enhancing the user experience with feature-rich options while maintaining the security benefits of MPC wallets to protect the EOA private key.

speakers.name: Phuc Thai
speakers.description: I received my PhD in Computer Science from Virginia Commonwealth University in 2023. Following this, I served as the head researcher at Sky Mavis, the innovative team behind Axie Infinity. I also contributed to the development of Ronin Network, an EVM blockchain specifically designed for gaming.

items.title: Building zk identity on-chain (Permisionless registries)
items.description: Discussing the creation of an on-chain registry system for storing zero-knowledge (zk) identities. This system will enable individuals to self-issue and control their data without a central authority, showcasing the ZK passport use case.
items.track: [CLS] d/acc Discovery Day: Building Towards a Resilient Utopia

speakers.name: Lasha
speakers.description: Building Rarimo protocol - zk identity registry. Creator of Freedomtool.org

items.title: "My mother will not use it"
items.description:
In this Talk, I want to cover the different mindsets designers need to improve and optimize the work for web3.
If we're going to change the way we interact with each other and aim to profoundly improve society with this technology, we can't think and use the same methodologies.
We will cover topics such as the target audience (the title of the Talk), testing, the learning curve, web2 to web3, and more.

speakers.name: Nuno Loureiro
speakers.description: Experienced designer with vast experience on web2 and transition to web3. Working to improve ethereum.org every day

items.title: The Ripple Effect of Devcon VI
items.description: Devcon VI in Bogot√° accelerated community growth across the region. Local communities emerged in several cities in Colombia and Latin America. The gathering provided leaders with a new perspective on enhancing collective creation for social impact and blockchain adoption. At ETH Bogot√°, we used this spark to transition from hosting general events to creating an educational system for developers and builders, aiming to push the adoption of blockchain and Ethereum in a new way.
items.tags: Vision,Ethereum for Good,Local Impact,education,Ethereum for Good,Local Impact,Vision

speakers.name: Julio Cesar Arango
speakers.description: I'm a generalist. Co-founder EducatETH, Blockchain Education Manager at ETH Kipu, and ETH Bogot√°. I have successfully led initiatives to boost the widespread adoption of Ethereum and its ecosystem among developers and builders in Latam through education and collective building.

items.title: Bootstrapping a block builder
items.description:
The sessions aims to be a practical overview of how to go from zero to having a running and reasonably competitive builder (profits may vary). It aims to answer the following questions:
- What software to run? How can this be customized?
- What would need to go into writing a builder from the ground up?
- How does one acquire orderflow? What is the relative value of various sources of orderflow?
- What infrastructure is required? How much does it cost?

speakers.name: Sean Anderson
speakers.description: Core protocol dev working on Lighthouse at Sigma Prime for the last ~4 years.

items.title: Check your user's humanity, nationality or age with privacy-preserving ID proofs!
items.description:
This workshop shows how to use the Proof of Passport SDK to check user's identity in a few lines of code. Let users generate zk proofs of age, nationality, humanity or non-inclusion in the OFAC list by scanning the NFC chip in their passport or ID card, and without ever having to reveal any private information.

Come try it now!

speakers.name: Florent
speakers.description:
Zero-knowledge cryptography.
Working on https://www.proofofpassport.com/

speakers.name: Michael Elliot
speakers.description: Michael is a research engineer with a focus on blockchain, cryptography, and zero-knowledge proofs.

speakers.name: R√©mi
speakers.description: Co-founder at OpenPassport

items.title: Exploring the Future of Account Abstraction
items.description: Discover the journey of Ethereum's Account Abstraction (AA) from inception to its current state, challenges tackled by ERC-4337, and future roadmap: modular native AA approach for L2 and L1, and EOA improvement (EIP-7702).
items.tags: Ethereum Roadmap,In-protocol Account Abstraction,Account Abstraction,aa,roadmap,Account Abstraction,Ethereum Roadmap,In-protocol Account Abstraction

items.title: hevm or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Symbolic Execution
items.description:
hevm is a symbolic execution engine for the EVM that can prove safety properties for EVM bytecode or verify semantic equivalence between two bytecode objects. It exposes a user-friendly API in Solidity that allows you to define symbolic tests using almost exactly the same syntax as usual unit tests.

In this talk, we'll present hevm, what it's useful for, and when and how to use it to help secure your digital contracts.

speakers.name: Mate Soos
speakers.description: Mate is a formal verification engineer at the Ethereum Foundation and occasionally does research in formal verification at various universities. He is currently working on hevm, a symbolic execution engine for finding issues with digital contracts.

items.title: The role of culture in shaping technology - the case against tech-neo-colonialism
items.description: Who builds technology and for whom? In decentralized technology, we must apply the cypherpunk ethos not only to the product we want to provide to the world but also to the manner we build that product. We must avoid imposing our worldview onto different cultures, or we risk reinventing tech neocolonialism. This talk will illustrate the risks of concentration of power and tech within our industry into the hands of a few cultures and present ways to build a truly cypherpunk future.

speakers.name: Fatemeh Fannizadeh
speakers.description: Fatemeh is an attorney focused on emerging technologies including blockchain, ai, privacy and their global social implications. She is currently general counsel of the Anoma Foundation in Switzerland. Born in Iran, educated at the University of Geneva and the London School of Economics, she writes on the mitigation of crypto legal risks, sanctions, and DAO regulations, while having lectured at the University of Geneva and the American University of Beirut.
